      • 2 ... c6
    • 1 ... e5
    • 1 ... d6
1. Nf3 f6 2. Nc3 Nh6 3. g4 c6 4. d4 e6 5. Ng5 f5 6. e4 g6 7. Rg1

6 ... g6 7. Rg1

6 ... g6 prevents Qh5-g6-Qg5 if black plays fxg4 but 7. Rg1 prevents fxg4.
7 ... Na6

7 ... Na6

8. Nb5

Nc7+ forces Qxc7 if black does not release the bishop to allow Kf8.

8 ... Nb4

9. Nc7+ Qxc7

10. Nxh7

8 ... Bb4+ 9. c3

After Bb4+, Black can't play Nb4 ... and also cannot play fxg4 because of Nc7-Kf8-Qf3+.

8 ... Bd6

9. Nxh7

Note that black can't play Bxh2 because of Nd6+.

9 ... Qh4 10. Rg3 Nb4 11. Bh6

11 ... Nxc2 12. Nc7+

12 ... Bxc7 13. exf5

12 ... Kd8 13. O-O-O

White threatens Bg7 followed by Bf6+.

13 ... Bf8

14. Bg7 Bxg7 15. Rh3

13 ... b6 14. d5

14 ... Bb4 15. Rc3

After 14 ... Bb4, white could play Rh3, but Rc3 is even better, blocking the bishop and also threatening dxc6 as well as Bg5+.

11 ... Kf7

12. d5 Kg8

13. dxe6

13 ... Nxc2 14. Nd6

14 ... b5

13 ... d5 14. Bf8

14. Bf8 stops Qe7.

9 ... Nb4 10. Bh6

Now consider Nb4-Bh6 without any Qh4-Rb3.

10 ... Qa5+ 11. c3

11 ... Nc2+ 12. Qxc2

White is up the material from the capture on h7 and black is up a queen, but black's queen is going to be captured for less than what white got on h7, and black can't play Bxh2 because white wins after Nd6-Ke7-Bf8+.

10 ... Kf7

11. Bg5
